---
# Potential Outcomes Framework

Let's introduce some notation:

- Let $Y_i$ be the observed outcome for unit $i$ (e.g. whether I have a headache or not in an hour).
- Let $Z_i$ be the treatment or intervention (e.g. taking a pill).

Then,

$$Y_i | Z_i = 1 \overset{\Delta}{=} Y_i(1) $$
where $Y_i(1)$ is the **.darkorange[potential outcome under treatment]**.

In the same fashion,

$$Y_i | Z_i = 0 \overset{\Delta}{=} Y_i(0) $$
where $Y_i(1)$ is the **.darkorange[potential outcome under control]**.

---
# Potential Outcomes Framework

This means that we can write the observed outcome as a function of the *potential outcomes*:

.box-5LA[$$\rightarrow Y_i = Z_i\cdot Y_i(1) + (1-Z_i)\cdot Y_i(0)$$]

- This definition will be useful because we can see this as a **.darkorange[missing data problem]**.

---
# Causal Effects

.box-4tL[Individual Causal Effect]

$$ICE_i = Y_i(1) - Y_i(0)$$
---

.box-4tL[Individual Causal Effect]

$$ICE_i = Y_i(1) - Y_i(0)$$

# Estimands vs Estimates vs Estimators

.pull-left-little_r[
.box-2[Estimand]

.box-2t[A quantity we want to estimate]

.box-2t[E.g.: Population mean]

.box-2t[$$\mu$$]
]
.pull-right-little_l[
.box-7[Estimate]

]
.center[
.box-4[Estimator]

<span class="box-4t">A rule for calculating<br>an 
estimate based on data</span>

.box-4t[E.g.: Sample mean]

.box-4t[$$\frac{1}{n}\sum_i Y_i$$]
]

# Estimands vs Estimates vs Estimators

- Some important **.darkorange[estimands]** that we need to keep in mind:

.box-3[Average Treatment Effect (ATE)]

.box-5[Average Treatment Effect on the Treated (ATT)]

.box-7[Conditional Average Treatment Effect (CATE)]

---
# Estimands vs Estimates vs Estimators

- Some important **.darkorange[estimands]** that we need to keep in mind:

.box-3[$$ATE = E[Y(1)- Y(0)]$$]

.box-5[$$ATT = E[Y(1)- Y(0)| Z=1]$$]

.box-7[$$CATE = E[Y(1)- Y(0)| X]$$]

# Under what assumptions is our estimate causal?

We are using:
$$\hat{\tau} = \frac{1}{3}(\sum_{i \in Z=1}Y_i - \sum_{i \in Z=0}Y_i)$$
to estimate:

$$\tau = E[Y_i(1) - Y_i(0)]$$

---
# Under what assumptions is our estimate causal?

We are using:
$$\hat{\tau} = \frac{1}{3}(\sum_{i \in Z=1}Y_i - \sum_{i \in Z=0}Y_i)$$

to estimate:

$$\tau = E[Y_i(1) - Y_i(0)]$$

.box-7LA[Let's do some math]

---
# Under what assumptions is our estimate causal?

$$\tau = E[Y_i(1) - Y_i(0)]$$
$$= E[Y_i(1)] - E[Y_i(0)]$$
**.darkorange[Key assumption]**:

.box-3[Ignorability]

- Ignorability means that the potential outcomes $Y(0)$ and $Y(1)$ are independent of the treatment, e.g. $(Y(0), Y(1)) \perp\!\!\!\perp Z$. 

---
# Under what assumptions is our estimate causal?

$$\tau = E[Y_i(1) - Y_i(0)]$$

.box-3[Ignorability]

- Ignorability means that the potential outcomes $Y(0)$ and $Y(1)$ are independent of the treatment, e.g. $(Y(0), Y(1)) \perp\!\!\!\perp Z$. 

  - *Remember that if* $A \perp\!\!\!\perp B \ \rightarrow \ E[A|B] = E[A]$

# Ignorability Assumption

It's the same as the **.darkorange[exchangeability assumption]**:

$$E[Y(1) | Z = 1] = E[Y(1)| Z=0] = E[Y(1)]$$

---
# Ignorability Assumption

It's the same as the **.darkorange[exchangeability assumption]**:

.center[![:scale 60%](https://github.com/maibennett/sta235/raw/main/exampleSite/content/Classes/Week3/1_PotentialOutcomes/images/ex3.png)]

$$E[Y(1) | Z = 1] = E[Y(1)| Z=0] = E[Y(1)]$$
$$E[Y(0) | Z = 1] = E[Y(0)| Z=0] = E[Y(0)]$$
---
# What happens if the ignorability assumption doesn't hold?

- Now, let's assume $(Y(0), Y(1)) \not\!\perp\!\!\!\perp Z$

$$\tau = E[Y_i(1)] - E[Y_i(0)] \neq E[Y_i| Z=1] - E[Y_i| Z=0]$$
.box-4LA[Correlation does not imply causation]

---
# What happens if the ignorability assumption doesn't hold?

- Now, let's assume $(Y(0), Y(1)) \not\!\perp\!\!\!\perp Z$

$$\tau = E[Y_i(1) - Y_i(0)] = $$
$$=E[Y_i(1) - Y_i(0)|Z=1]Pr(Z=1) + E[Y_i(1) - Y_i(0)|Z=1](1-Pr(Z=1))$$
---
# What happens if the ignorability assumption doesn't hold?

- Now, let's assume $(Y(0), Y(1)) \not\!\perp\!\!\!\perp Z$

$$\tau = E[Y_i(1) - Y_i(0)] = $$

$$=\color{#900DA4}{\underbrace{E[Y_i(1) - Y_i(0)|Z=1]}_\text{ATT}}Pr(Z=1) + \color{#F89441}{\overbrace{E[Y_i(1) - Y_i(0)|Z=0]}^\text{ATC}}(1-Pr(Z=1))$$
- Weighted average of the ATT and ATC.

---
# What happens if the ignorability assumption doesn't hold?

- After some simple math, you can get to:

$$\tau = E[Y_i(1) - Y_i(0)] = ATE$$

$$\begin{aligned}
ATE &=E[Y_i|Z=1] - E[Y_i|Z=0] \\
\\
& - (E[Y_i(0)|Z=1]-E[Y_i(0)|Z=0]) \\
\\
& - (1-Pr(Z=1))(ATT - ATC)
\end{aligned}$$
<br>
<br>
<br>
<br>
.source[Check out [Scott Cunningham's "Causal Inference: The Mixtape" (Ch. 4.1.3)](https://mixtape.scunning.com/ch3.html) for the decomposition]

---
# What happens if the ignorability assumption doesn't hold?

- After some simple math, you can get to:

$$\tau = E[Y_i(1) - Y_i(0)] = ATE$$

$$\begin{aligned}
ATE &=\color{#900DA4}{\underbrace{E[Y_i|Z=1] - E[Y_i|Z=0]}_\text{Obs diff in means}} \\
& - \color{#E16462}{\underbrace{(E[Y_i(0)|Z=1]-E[Y_i(0)|Z=0])}_\text{Selection bias}} \\
& - \color{#FCCE25}{\underbrace{(1-Pr(Z=1))(ATT - ATC)}_\text{Heterogeneous treat. effect bias}}
\end{aligned}$$
- **.darkorange[Selection Bias:]** Difference between groups if they both were under control.
- **.darkorange[Heterogeneous Treatment Effect Bias:]** Difference in returns to treatment for the two groups (weighted by the control population).
<br>
.source[Check out [Scott Cunningham's "Causal Inference: The Mixtape" (Ch. 4.1.3)](https://mixtape.scunning.com/ch3.html) for the decomposition]

# How would bias look like?

```{r PO1, fig.height=5.5, fig.width=7.5, fig.align='center', dev='svg', echo=FALSE, warning=FALSE, message = FALSE}
periods = 10
n = 100

for(p in 1:periods){
  set.seed(p)
  
  t_aux = rep(p,n)
  y0_0_aux = rnorm(100, 0, 0.5)
  y1_0_aux = 0.5 + 0.01*p + rnorm(100, 0, 0.5)
  
  y0_1_bias_aux = -0.3 - 0.01*p + rnorm(100, 0, 0.5)
  
  y1_1_hetero_aux = 1 + 0.02*p + rnorm(100, 0, 0.5)
 
  if(p==1){
    t = t_aux
    y0_0 = y0_0_aux
    y1_0 = y1_0_aux
    
    y0_1_bias = y0_1_bias_aux
    y1_1_hetero = y1_1_hetero_aux
  } 
  
    if(p>1){
    t = c(t,t_aux)
    y0_0 = c(y0_0,y0_0_aux)
    y1_0 = c(y1_0,y1_0_aux)
    
    y0_1_bias = c(y0_1_bias,y0_1_bias_aux)
    y1_1_hetero = c(y1_1_hetero,y1_1_hetero_aux)
  } 
}

d = data.frame("t" = t,
               "y0_0" = y0_0,
               "y1_0" = y1_0,
               "y0_1_bias" = y0_1_bias,

ggplot(data = d, aes(x = t, y = y0_0)) +
  geom_smooth(method = "gam", se=FALSE, lty=2, color = "#900DA4", lwd=1.4) +
```

.box-3LA[Confounder]

# Is "Visited the website" a confounder?

# Is "Visited the website" a confounder?

- **.darkorange[Measured after the intervention:]** Don't know $\rightarrow$ Intervention might have incentivized people to go to the website, and registering also had on effect on traffic.

# Scenario 1: Confounding

**.darkorange[Data Generating Process]**:
  
  - No treatment effect.
  
  - Pr(Registering | Visit) < Pr(Registering | Not Visited)
  
  - Due to data collection, more people in the mailing sample had visited the website than people in the email sample.

.small[
.center[
```{r echo = FALSE}
set.seed(122)

# Confounding:

# probability of registering depending on whether you've visited the website or not (and are reminded of it)
prob_nv <- 0.203
prob_v <- 0.142

y1_nv <- sample(c(0,1),1436,replace = TRUE, prob = c(1-prob_nv,prob_nv))
y1_v <- sample(c(0,1),614,replace = TRUE, prob = c(1-prob_v,prob_v))

treat_nv <- sample(c("m","e"), 1436, replace = TRUE, prob = c(36/1436,1-36/1436))
treat_v <- sample(c("m","e"), 614, replace = TRUE, prob = c(514/614,1-514/614))

confound <- data.frame("id" = seq(1,2050),
                       "visit" = c(rep(0,1436),rep(1,614)),
                       "treat" = c(treat_nv,treat_v),
                       "y" = c(y1_nv, y1_v))

tab1 <- table(confound$treat,confound$visit)
tab2 <- round(table(confound$treat[confound$visit==0],confound$y[confound$visit==0])[,2]/rowSums(table(confound$treat[confound$visit==0],confound$y[confound$visit==0])),2)
tab3 <- round(table(confound$treat[confound$visit==1],confound$y[confound$visit==1])[,2]/rowSums(table(confound$treat[confound$visit==1],confound$y[confound$visit==1])),2)
tab4 <- round(table(confound$treat,confound$y)[,2]/rowSums(table(confound$treat,confound$y)),2)

tab <- cbind(tab1, tab2, tab3, tab4)
colnames(tab) <- c("Not visited","Visited", "Registered - NV","Registered - V","Registered - Total")

rownames(tab) <- c("Email","Mail")


tbl <- tab %>%
  reactable(
      # ALL one page (no scrolling or page swapping)
    pagination = TRUE,
    rownames = TRUE,
    # compact for an overall smaller table width wise
    compact = FALSE,
    # borderless - TRUE or FALSE
    borderless = FALSE,
    # Stripes - TRUE or FALSE
    striped = TRUE,
    # fullWidth - either fit to width or not
    fullWidth = FALSE,
    # apply defaults
    # 100 px and align to center of column
    defaultColDef = colDef(
      align = "center",
      minWidth = 180
  ),
  columns = list(
    "Registered - NV" = colDef(style = list(borderLeft = "1px solid rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.1)")),
    "Registered - Total" = colDef(style = list(borderLeft = "1px solid rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.1)"))
  ),
    style = list(fontFamily = "Fira Sans, sans-serif")
  )

div(
  # this class can be called with CSS now via .salary
  class = "tab",
  div(
    # this can be called with CSS now via .title
    class = "title",
    h3("Num in Sample and % of New Registrations by Type of Campaign and Visits to the Website")
  ),
  # The actual table
  tbl
)
```
]]

# Scenario 2: Collider Bias

**.darkorange[Data Generating Process]**:
  
  - No direct treatment effect of mailing over emails.
  
  - Pr(Visit | e-mail) < Pr(Visit | mail)
  
  - People that receive a letter are much more encouraged to visit the website, and people that register are also more likely to visit the website.

.small[
.center[
```{r echo = FALSE}
set.seed(120)

treat <- sample(c("m","e"), 2050, replace = TRUE, prob = c(1-0.732,0.732))

y1 <- sample(c(0,1), 2050, replace = TRUE, prob=c(1-0.1843,0.1843))

visit_e_0 <- sample(c(0,1),sum(treat=="e" & y1==0),replace = TRUE, prob = c(1-90/1210,90/1210))
visit_e_1 <- sample(c(0,1),sum(treat=="e" & y1==1),replace = TRUE, prob = c(1-10/290,10/290))

visit_m_0 <- sample(c(0,1),sum(treat=="m" & y1==0),replace = TRUE, prob = c(1-437/462,437/462))
visit_m_1 <- sample(c(0,1),sum(treat=="m" & y1==1),replace = TRUE, prob = c(1-77/88,77/88))

visit <- 0
visit[which(treat=="m" & y1==0)] <- visit_m_0
visit[which(treat=="m" & y1==1)] <- visit_m_1
visit[which(treat=="e" & y1==0)] <- visit_e_0
visit[which(treat=="e" & y1==1)] <- visit_e_1

collider <- data.frame("id" = seq(1,2050),
                       "visit" = visit,
                       "treat" = treat,
                       "y" = y1)


tab1 <- table(collider$treat,collider$visit)
tab2 <- round(table(collider$treat[collider$visit==0],collider$y[collider$visit==0])[,2]/rowSums(table(collider$treat[collider$visit==0],collider$y[collider$visit==0])),2)
tab3 <- round(table(collider$treat[collider$visit==1],collider$y[collider$visit==1])[,2]/rowSums(table(collider$treat[collider$visit==1],collider$y[collider$visit==1])),2)
tab4 <- round(table(collider$treat,collider$y)[,2]/rowSums(table(collider$treat,collider$y)),2)

tab <- cbind(tab1, tab2, tab3, tab4)
colnames(tab) <- c("Not visited","Visited", "Registered - NV","Registered - V","Registered - Total")

rownames(tab) <- c("Email","Mail")


tbl <- tab %>%
  reactable(
      # ALL one page (no scrolling or page swapping)
    pagination = TRUE,
    rownames = TRUE,
    # compact for an overall smaller table width wise
    compact = FALSE,
    # borderless - TRUE or FALSE
    borderless = FALSE,
    # Stripes - TRUE or FALSE
    striped = TRUE,
    # fullWidth - either fit to width or not
    fullWidth = FALSE,
    # apply defaults
    # 100 px and align to center of column
    defaultColDef = colDef(
      align = "center",
      minWidth = 180
  ),
  columns = list(
    "Registered - Toal" = colDef(style = list(borderLeft = "1px solid rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.1)"))
  ),
    style = list(fontFamily = "Fira Sans, sans-serif")
  )

div(
  # this class can be called with CSS now via .salary
  class = "tab",
  div(
    # this can be called with CSS now via .title
    class = "title",
    h3("Num in Sample and % of New Registrations by Type of Campaign and Visits to the Website")
  ),
  # The actual table
  tbl
)
```

# Let's check our data

  - **.darkorange[Binary Treatment]**: Beauty above average (1) vs Below average (0)

.small[
```{r echo = TRUE, message=FALSE, results = 'hide'}
profs <- profs %>% mutate(treat = as.numeric(beauty > 0),
                          female = 2 - as.numeric(gender),
                          single_credit = as.numeric(credits)-1,
                          upper_div = as.numeric(division)-1,
                          native = as.numeric(native)-1,
                          tenure = as.numeric(tenure)-1,
                          minority = as.numeric(minority)-1) 

library(designmatch)

covs <- profs %>% dplyr::select(minority, age, female, single_credit, upper_div, 
                                native, tenure, students, allstudents)

meantab(covs, profs$treat, which(profs$treat==1), which(profs$treat==0))
```
